January 26, 1953
THIRD REVISED MEMORANDUM CM TOCQUEVILLE PROJEC'
By Phillips Bradley, SyracuseUniversity
Robert E. Streeter, University of Chicago
George E.Probst, University of Chicago
Purpose: (l) To communicate some of Tocqueville9s significant
ideas on the relationship among equality, democracy, and liberty, and
his enduring social and economic observations. (2) To bring to the pre¬
sent the counsel of the wisdom of Tocqueville. (3) To convey a sense of
history as something as living as the immediate present.
Scheme; This series of half-hour dramatic programs will
roughly follow-the course of Tocqueville9s journey to and in America in
1831-32. The series will begin and end in Paris. The background and
motivation will be the hope of finding a peaceful and evolutionary path
for political and social change. He is in search of an alternative to
the French revolutionary, destructive violence by the mass of the people
against the entrenched rights of property. America is seen as the per¬
sonification of the equality that he sees as inevitable for France and,
indeed, all Europe. Tocqueville travels to America to seek the knowledge
that will give intelligent guidance for the conservative who is interested
in securing liberty and safety from the tyranny of the majority.
In a series of dramatic episodes, Tocqueville will be revealed
in the process of accumulating experience and insight into the strengths
and weaknesses of the American society. It is a developmental series,
for Tocqueville will possess initially the misconceptions of the French
aristocrat. He will come to a full integration of his new view of America
over a period of time. The simple experiences and plain concepts will be
put first in the time of his experience. (E.g., it is in September in
Boston, after landing in New York in the previous May, that Tocqueville
comes to the view that the American experiment would not soon fail, as
his family and friends believed.) The more elaborate notions will be put
later in the series and emphasized in a recapitulation of central ideas
after his return to Paris.
For illustrative dramatic material, contemporary novels, news¬
papers, letters, books, will be drawn upon to secure the "capsule inci¬
dent" which depicts Tocqueville9s generalization. Anything may be used
that Tocqueville could have witnessed, read, or fceard reported.
Fictitious interviews with people Tocqueville did not meet are not ac¬
ceptable. Tocqueville is the narrator, and at the same time a partici¬
pant in the dramatic episodes as seems necessary. Contemporary relevance
to 1953 is to be achieved (l) through a choice of the most appropriate
materials of the 18309s in America which are still significant; and (2)
through a simplicity and directness in Tocqueville9s words which achieves
